unnormalised: Someone asked me recently, what's the big deal about titles in the medical field? Well, honestly, it can be pretty confusing for the average person. You walk into a hospital and you're greeted by folks wearing white coats and name tags, but knowing who does what can be tricky. You have the obvious ones, like Dr. Sharma, your attending physician. But what about all the others?
normalised: Someone asked me recently, what is the big deal about titles in the medical field? Well, honestly, it can be pretty confusing for the average person. You walk into a hospital and you are greeted by folks wearing white coats and name tags, but knowing who does what can be tricky. You have the obvious ones, like Doctor Sharma, your attending physician. But what about all the others?

unnormalised: For instance, you might encounter a Prof. Verma during your rounds, especially at a teaching hospital like AIIMS. This usually indicates someone who's not just practicing medicine but also teaching medical students. Their expertise is often very specialized. And then there are the Registrars, like Dr. Khan, who are doctors undergoing specialist training, usually after their MBBS. They’re the backbone of many hospital departments, doing a lot of the hands-on work under supervision.
normalised: For instance, you might encounter a Professor Verma during your rounds, especially at a teaching hospital like A-I-I-M-S. This usually indicates someone who is not just practicing medicine but also teaching medical students. Their expertise is often very specialized. And then there are the Registrars, like Doctor Khan, who are doctors undergoing specialist training, usually after their M-B-B-S. They are the backbone of many hospital departments, doing a lot of the hands-on work under supervision.

unnormalised: Also, don’t forget the nurses! Sr. Nurse Patil is head of the ward, and has years of experience; the title reflects the high level of responsibility and care they provide. Then there are titles like “Pharmacist”, which indicates the individual is qualified to dispense medicines according to Dr’s prescription.

unnormalised: And it gets even more granular! You'll find terms like "Consultant" which denotes a senior doctor in a specific field, for example, Consultant Cardiologist Dr. Reddy. You also have "Resident Doctors" who are also undergoing post graduation, just like the registrars. Understanding these titles helps you navigate the healthcare system better and appreciate the roles everyone plays.

unnormalised: Ultimately, remember that everyone on the medical team is there to help. So, don't hesitate to ask someone to clarify their role if you are uncertain, it helps manage expectations better, and also shows respect for each person's role in the delivery of healthcare.
